Package me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.configuration

Class Configuration

java.lang.Object
me.wobblyyyy.rlibx.configuration.Configuration
Direct Known Subclasses:
SubsystemConfiguration
public class Configuration
extends java.lang.Object
A template class for anything related to configurations.

In essence, this class is a wrapper for the HashMap class we all know and love. My reasoning behind this abstraction was that a custom class we can construct easily is significantly more maneuverable in a situation like this one.

Since:
0.1.0
Author:
Colin Robertson

  • Field Details

    • values

      private final java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Double> values
      All of the stored keys and values.

      The values contained in this HashMap shouldn't ever be modified directly - all modifications to the HashMap should come from a getter or setter method defined elsewhere in the Configuration class.

      See Also:
      getDouble(String), getInt(String), add(String, double), Configuration(HashMap)

  • Constructor Details

    • Configuration

      public Configuration​(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Double> values)
      Create a new configuration with a set of values.

      The values that should be set are notated in a HashMap form, with String keys and Double values. These String keys should almost always be abstracted through an enum, just to ensure that there aren't any spelling mistakes, etc. The double values can represent integers as well. To put an integer where a double would normally go, you can simply put the double form of that integer. Ex: 

       put("Test", 1);   // Not a double, wouldn't work.
 put("Test", 1.0); // Is a double, everything works fine.
      The Configuration class will handle conversion between doubles and integers for you, so long as you use the correct method when attempting to request a double or an integer. For reference:
      • Doubles should be attained with: getDouble(String)
      • Integers should be obtained with: getInt(String)

      Parameters:
      values - the values that should be set.
      See Also:
      add(String, double)

  • Method Details

    • isAnInteger

      private boolean isAnInteger​(double number)
      Check whether or not a given number is an integer.
      Parameters:
      number - the number to check.
      Returns:
      whether or not that number is an integer.

    • getDouble

      public double getDouble​(java.lang.String key)
      Get a double value based on a given key.

      Numbers are stored as doubles by default, meaning there's no need to run any conversions or casts in order to extract a usable value.

      Parameters:
      key - the key to search for.
      Returns:
      a found double value.
      See Also:
      getInt(String)

    • getInt

      public int getInt​(java.lang.String key)
      Get an integer value based on a key.

      If the value requested is NOT an integer, a NotAnInteger exception is thrown to warn the user that the number they've requested is not an integer, and, as a result, will not work.

      If we can't find an integer value with the given key, we return -1. -1 doesn't have any significance or impact or reasoning behind it, aside from the fact I thought it would be a good option to choose for a situation like this. Just a heads up, y'know?

      Parameters:
      key - the key to search for.
      Returns:
      an integer, based on the results of searching for the key.
      See Also:
      getDouble(String), isAnInteger(double)

    • add

      public void add​(java.lang.String key, double value)
      Add a configuration option.

      Attempting to add a new configuration option for something that already exists will simply replace the older configuration option. As a practical example of this, take: 

       add("test", 1D); // test's value: 1
 add("test", 2D); // test's value: 2
 add("aaaa", 3D); // test's value: 2
 add("test", 4D); // test's value: 4

      Parameters:
      key - the configuration option's key represented as a String. This is the name of the configuration option and what will need to be queried later. Configuration options should typically use enums to ensure that there aren't any spelling mistakes, etc.
      value - the configuration option's value. Integer values should be entered as doubles without any decimal numbers aside from zero. Double numbers can be entered as intended.
      See Also:
      Configuration(HashMap), values
